bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 161, Number 163 (Tuesday, November 3, 2015)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. SCHRADER:H.R. 3915.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:This bill is enacted pursuant to the power granted toCongress under:U.S. Const. art. 1, Sec. 1; andU.S. Const. art. 1, Sec. 8, cl. 18.[Page H7625]

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs.

summary.text:
US Navy SEAL SCPO Tyrone Snowden Woods Ceremony Invitee Act of 2015

This bill directs the Department of State to:

  • prescribe a policy by which a member of a diplomatic mission may designate those next-of-kin who will be invited to, and be entitled to attend, any memorial service held to honor the member in the event of his or her death in service to the United States; and
  • publicize such policy and make the appropriate forms available to each member of a diplomatic mission.

bill.title: US Navy SEAL SCPO Tyrone Snowden Woods Ceremony Invitee Act of 2015

item.title: US Navy SEAL SCPO Tyrone Snowden Woods Ceremony Invitee Act of 2015

To ensure that United States Government personnel, including members of the Armed Forces and contractors, assigned to United States diplomatic missions are given the opportunity to designate next-of-kin for certain purposes in the event of the death of the personnel.
US Navy SEAL SCPO Tyrone Snowden Woods Ceremony Invitee Act of 2015

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
